channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Amid Fear and Pressure, Syrians Vote for President
item.description: The election is certain to confirm Bashar al-Assad’s hold on power amid a civil war that has killed an estimated 160,000 Syrians.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: A man votes for President Bashar al-Assad, marking his ballot with blood. The vote in Syria is expected to hand Mr. Assad another seven-year term.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Chic Idea for China’s Green-Minded Set
item.description: A Hong Kong-based environmental movement to clean up the textile and apparel industry is recruiting young talent to make the concept of eco fashion more attractive to the urban middle class in China.
item.dc:creator: By SHAOJIE HUANG
item.media:description: A garment factory in Jiujiang in central China's Jiangxi Province.

item.title: New Fighting Reported in Eastern Ukraine
item.description: Ukraine’s interior minister said that separatist fighters had attacked government vehicles but that the attack had been repulsed.
item.dc:creator: By SABRINA TAVERNISE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Chen Guang on the Soldiers Who Retook Tiananmen Square
item.description: Chen Guang, one of the soldiers ordered to clear the protesters from Tiananmen Square in 1989, describes those days in an interview conducted before his detention by the Chinese authorities in the lead-up to the anniversary of the crackdown.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: Residents of Beijing surrounded soldiers to prevent them from continuing to Tiananmen Square on May 20, 1989 after martial law was declared.

item.title: Bowe Bergdahl’s Vanishing Before Capture Angered His Unit
item.description: The release of the U.S. soldier has created political problems for the Obama administration, which is having to defend his exchange for five Taliban detainees.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT, HELENE COOPER and CHARLIE SAVAGE.

item.title: Fearing Converts to Terrorism, France Intercepts Citizens Bound for Syria
item.description: Amid worries about a threat from radicalized Europeans who fight in Syria and then return, France is being especially aggressive, arresting would-be jihadis even before they leave the country.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: Relatives in Tel Aviv mourn those killed at the Jewish Museum in Brussels. The suspect was said to have spent time in Syria.

item.title: DealBook: French Officials Twist U.S. Arms in Bank Inquiry
item.description: The French campaign has focused largely on the concern that BNP, unlike other big banks accused of doing business with Sudan and Iran, might be forced to suspend a core business operation in New York as a result of the guilty plea.
item.dc:creator: By BEN PROTESS and JESSICA SILVER-GREENBERG
item.media:description: President Francois Hollande of France reviews troops in the courtyard of the Invalides in Paris.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Liu Heung Shing on Photographing Tiananmen
item.description: The most intense moments of the Hong Kong-based photojournalist Liu Heung Shing’s career came when he was a witness to the Tiananmen Square protests in 1989.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: A tricycle cart driver peddled wounded people to a nearby hospital on June 4, 1989.

item.title: Citing Pressure and Threats, Egypt’s Answer to Jon Stewart Calls It Quits
item.description: Bassem Youssef, a satirist who poked fun at the politically powerful, said he was ending his television show out of concern for his safety and that of his family.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and MAYY EL SHEIKH
item.media:description: Bassem Youssef, a satirist who took on post-revolutionary Egypt, said Monday at a news conference in Cairo that he was ending his television show.

item.title: Separatists Attack a Border Guard Headquarters in Eastern Ukraine
item.description: The station, whose function is to check for smuggled goods, not to fight paramilitary forces, was under siege for more than 12 hours.
item.dc:creator: By SABRINA TAVERNISE
item.media:description: Separatist fighters during an attack on a district border control headquarters on Monday in the eastern Ukrainian city of Luhansk.

item.title: Tales of Army Discord Show Tiananmen Square in a New Light
item.description: In 1989, a Chinese general refused to take part in violence against protesters, sending tremors through the Communist Party establishment, documents and interviews show.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Residents and soldiers on the street in Beijing on June 6, 1989 after the crackdown on protesters.

item.title: World Briefing: Dust Storm in Iran Smothers the Capital
item.description: A heavy dust storm roared into Iran’s capital on Monday, blacking out the sun in a swirling cloud and tearing down trees in a squall that reportedly killed at least four people and injured 30.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: 2 North Koreans to Defect
item.description: South Korea announced Monday that it would respect the wishes of two North Koreans to defect after their boat drifted into the South’s waters, but said that it would return a third who wanted to go back to North Korea.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Abuse Reports for TV Star Rise
item.description: The television presenter Jimmy Savile was a far more prolific sex offender than previously suspected, a charity said Monday, citing at least 500 reports of abuse involving children as young as 2 and victims in a high-security psychiatric hospital.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Protests in Nigeria Over Captives Banned
item.description: The police in Abuja, the capital, said Monday that they had banned protests organized to demand that the government rescue more than 200 girls still held captive by Boko Haram militants.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Clashes Spread Panic in Benghazi
item.description: Helicopters attacked camps and strongholds of Islamist militias on Monday in eastern Libya as part of a nearly three-week offensive by a renegade general.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Iraq: Attacks Kill at Least 15 People
item.description: Attacks across Iraq on Monday hit commercial areas and Iraqi security forces, killing at least 15 people and wounding dozens, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Anger Among Indians After Killings of 2 Girls
item.description: The rape and hanging of two girls have incited outrage in India and fury against the state government and the police.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA
item.media:description: The grandmother of two Indian girls who were raped and hanged in India’s Uttar Pradesh state.

item.title: Recorded Noise Might Offer Clues to Missing Plane
item.description: A low-frequency noise might have indicated an ocean impact, and scientists are to provide details on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Strategy and Objectives for Gaining Soldier’s Release Shifted Over Time
item.description: For more than two years, the Obama administration maneuvered to make a deal to free Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl the start of a larger peace process for Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and ASHLEY PARKER
item.media:description: Stickers showing support for Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl at Zaney’s coffee shop in Hailey, Idaho, where the soldier worked as a teenager.

item.title: Memo From the Hague: Politics Seen Undercutting Credibility of a Court
item.description: Critics cite The Hague’s complicated relationship with the United States and say it is sometimes a forum for nations to criticize their adversaries.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: China Escalating Attack on Google
item.description: The Chinese authorities have blocked global versions of the company’s search engines, and Gmail, Calendar and Translate have been affected.
item.dc:creator: By DAN LEVIN
item.media:description: A file photo of Google's main office in Beijing.

item.title: Secret Global Strike Kills 2 Malicious Web Viruses
item.description: A coordinated effort by government agents in the United States and Europe aimed at two pernicious viruses also led to the identity of the Russian man suspected of masterminding the malware.
item.dc:creator: By MATT APUZZO
item.media:description: Assistant Attorney General Leslie Caldwell, at podium, announces criminal charges and a coordinated strike against two global cyberfraud operations.

item.title: Open Source: Thai Protesters Flash ‘Hunger Games’ Salute to Register Quiet Dissent
item.description: Thailand’s military junta is unsure how to treat citizens who make a three-fingered salute, a sign of resistance borrowed from “The Hunger Games.”
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Ciro de Quadros, 74, Dies; Leader in Ridding Latin America of Polio
item.description: Dr. de Quadros navigated war zones and reimagined outmoded public health practices to lead a successful immunization campaign in Latin America and the Caribbean.
item.dc:creator: By PAUL VITELLO
item.media:description: Ciro de Quadros, center, in Ethiopia in 1971. He is widely credited with carrying out one of the boldest projects in modern epidemiological history that eradicated polio in Latin America and the Caribbean.
